title: Salt-affected soils: discovering a missed reality

tasks.task: Understanding salt-affected soils and their impact on agriculture.
subtasks: Identifying the components of salt-affected soils (saline and sodic).
Explaining how soluble salts make it hard for plants to absorb water.
Describing the characteristics of sodic soils (hard and compact when dry, sticky when wet).
Recognizing the reduction in agricultural productivity caused by siline and sodic conditions.
Analyzing the global extent of salt-affected soils (833 million hectares, 73% of global land area).
Discussing natural drivers of salt-affected soils in arid, semi-arid, and coastal environments.
Giving an example of a natural siline soil landscape (Ayuni salt flat in Bolivia and its crop production).
Identifying human-induced drivers of salinization and sodification (unsustainable agriculture, irrigation with poor water, etc.).
Considering the effects of climate change on coastal soils (seawater intrusion causing salinity).
Conserving natural ecosystems prone to salt and sodicity.
Practicing sustainable soil and water management.
Implementing appropriate irrigation techniques and adapted crops for affected soils.
Promoting the harmonic coexistence of salt management with natural ecosystems.
Encouraging collaborative efforts to prevent soil salinization and enhance productivity.
